IRD_def: Researchers of different religions meet once a month for comparative scripture reading. The aim is to read texts of different religious traditions related to a specific topic each time. Members of the Institute will select the topics of the workshop in turn, and other members will choose the texts from each religious tradition under the specified topic and arrange them together as reading materials. The process of comparative scripture reading will include exegesis, comparison and dialogue.

IRD_activities.activity: A school for dialogue in the Focolare town at Tagaytay

structure: General Council, consisting of woman President, general counsellors, persons in charge of sections and central activities and representatives of the Movement in the various countries. Sections: (i) Focolarini - individual lay people living in small communities of men or women, known as 'Focolare', joined by married people living in their own homes but part of the communities, known as 'Married Focolarini'; the Focolare are the basic structure of the Movement. (ii) 'Volunteers' - men and women living in their own homes but totally sharing the spirituality of the Focolare and committed to live this spirituality in the various environments in which they work in order to bring about a renewal of society. (iii) 'Priests' - who have taken the Focolare spirituality as their own and with it animate their pastoral and ecclesial life. (iv) Movement of Religious Men and Women - Movement of men or women belonging to different congregations, sharing the spirituality of Focolare. (v) 'Gen' - young people (boys and girls) who commit themselves in a total way to live the Focolare spirituality and work with the other sections to bring about unity in the world.
other_relations: No information
IRD_def: The Focolare Movement is committed to promoting dialogue between religions, because the religious pluralism of the world should not be a cause of division and war, but contribute to the building of brotherhood and world peace.
events: 2011: Philippines: at the school of religions: The School for Oriental Religions in Tagaytay gathered 250 participants from different countries to learn to dialogue in a spirit of reciprocal respect, Manila, Philippines

2012: Sophia Institute: Buddhism and Fraternity: The thesis of the first Buddhist student at the University Institute in Loppiano, comparing the thought of Buddhadasa Bhikkhu and Chiara Lubich, Florence, Italy

2012: Worldwide educators meet in Rome: How can we best educate children in human values and faith? How can we give them an experience of God's love? These were questions raised by 180 educators from all over the world who attended a week of study and reflection, Rome, Italy

2013: The human person in Sub-Saharan Africa: A 10th course on inculturation has taken place at Mariapolis Piero's Centre for Inculturation. The 287 participants included clergy, laity and young people from all the geographic region of the African continent, Nairobi, Kenya

2013: Chiara Lubich: A Charism Between History and Culture: More than 600 people, including professors and scholars, gather at La Spapienza University to remember the figure of the Focolare founder, tracing the development and actualisations of her spiritual doctrine, Rome, Italy

history: Norwegian Church Aid began in 1947 as a small fundraising drive by Norwegian churches. Today, NCA is one of the Nordic countries’ largest aid organisations.

aim: Develop as bodhisattvas and realise Shakyamuni Buddha's message: all beings are on this Path and to bring peace to our families, communities, countries, and to the world.

general_activities.activity_description: Since 1974, Rissho Kosei-kai has conducted 'Donate-a-Meal Movement' and the money contributed by its members through the campaign has been accumulated as the Rissho Kosei-kai Donate-a-Meal Fund for Peace and is utilized for its wide variety of activities for world peace;

In 1978, Rissho Kosei-kai established the Niwano Peace Foundation as one of the commemorative undertakings for the 40th anniversary of the organization's founding. Rissho Kosei-kai hopes that the foundation will contribute to the attainment of world peace through the encouragement of people of religion everywhere to cooperate toward this goal, as well as through the enhancement of cultural and educational activities based on the religious spirit; 4. Since 1980, the foundation has awarded the Niwano Peace Prize to honour remarkable religious leaders or groups that contribute to world peace through interreligious dialogue, protection of human rights, and conflict resolution. The foundation also provides financial assistance for religiously inspired research activities and projects concerning thought, culture, science, education, and related subjects; 5. Carrying out own religious activities (studying the Lotus Sutra and the Buddha's teachings);

With the cooperation of other nongovernmental organizations, Rissho Kosei-kai launched the Little Bags of Dreams Campaign in 1999, in this annual campaign, conducted from late April through the end of August, elementary and junior high school students fill little cloth bags with stationery items, small daily necessities, toys, and cards containing messages of friendship at home with their parents or in their respective churches with friends and other members;

general_activities.activity_name: Sharing Blankets with People in Africa
general_activities.activity_description: Rissho Kosei-kai's participation in the campaign from 1984 is based on the spirit as sharing in suffering, offering prayers, and making donations for the refugees who have suffered from wars or natural disasters in Africa; 8. ARMS DOWN! Campaign which was led by youth from the world's religions work to engage religious leaders and believers around the world to unleash the power of multi-religious cooperation through shared action;

Rissho Kosei-kai aims to help build peace and prosperity in the home, the community, the nation, and the world. As a Buddhist organization, Rissho Kosei-kai sometimes takes strong stances on political issues in order to promote social harmony and world peace. Rissho Kosei-kai considers its political activities to be a form of bodhisattva practice and speaks out on political issues to defend freedom of religion and the sanctity of life for the sake of world peace;

history: The organization was founded by Nikkyo Niwano and Myoko Naganuma in 1938, guided by the teachings of the Lotus Sutra and the spirit of Shakyamuni Buddh.

aim: Committed to the development and implementation of innovative, sustainable strategies for conflict transformation and community reconciliation in societies where ethnic, religious, sectarian, or political conflict threatens the possibility of a healthy, inclusive democracy and sustainable development.
publications: 'Peacebuilding in Divided Communities': Karuna Center's Approach to Peacebuilding

general_activities.activity_description: The programs explore the interweaving of social, political, and economic factors that contribute to conflict, recognizing that conflict transformation requires both individual and systemic change. They engage participants in analyzing the root causes of conflict, identifying strategic opportunities for intervention, and building skills for conflict resolution and prevention by applying the approach fits with local culture and respects the needs of those deeply impacted by violence and trauma;

Central to the work of Karuna Center is the skilful use of facilitated, structured dialogues. During well-facilitated dialogues participants can come to a profound recognition of the essential humanity of the other, to a sense of mutuality and common purpose, and to a willingness to move forward together;

The longer term programs include a "training of trainers" and mentoring in the design and delivery of peacebuilding projects. Former participants of Karuna Center programs not only bring social healing to their communities, but also facilitate dialogues and teach peacebuilding skills throughout their countries. They are thereby helping to build a critical mass of people committed to promoting peace and justice and preventing future violence;
Advocating to build consensus around the idea that putting a price on carbon by facilitating the Summit and discussions through local dialogues;

aim: Based on the gospel and inspired by faith, the organisation aims to transform a world shaken by violence, terrorism, deepening inequalities and global insecurity; to create a culture of peace with religion as an unequivocal force for peace and social justice; to work towards non-violence, demilitarization and disarmament, human security, human rights and the rule of law as the basis of peaceful societies; to bring together people from various backgrounds and cultures.

general_activities.activity_description: Pax Christi facilitates and supports reconciliation and peace building processes which help communities to look at the past and develop a path towards lasting peace rooted in truth and justice (Just Peace). Pax Christi promotes peacekeeping skills of dialogue, mediation, and conflict resolution;
Pax Christi contributes to a culture of peace by encouraging models of education that use, for example, youth exchanges, alternative peace service, voluntary peace work, and peace weeks;

Pax Christi's dedication to peace is translated into the countless nonviolent actions of its members around the world. This includes organising conferences and debates, defending the rights of conscientious objectors, efforts to heal ethnic or religious divisions, solidarity delegations and missions to areas of conflict, and public witness for peace;

general_activities.activity_name: Interfaith and Intercultural Cooperation for Peace
general_activities.activity_description: Pax Christi creates opportunities for inter-faith dialogue and cooperation in order to promote peace and social justice with efforts towards Islam and Muslim communities;
By developing a spirituality and theology of peace to insert moral and ethical principles on issues of war and peace into the public and political arenas;

Through its representative status with international bodies such as the United Nations, UNESCO, the EU, and the Council of Europe, Pax Christi brings the experiences and concerns of its members in the Global Network to the international arena. On a national level, Pax Christi Member Organisations engage in advocacy appropriate to their own unique social and political context;

Pax Christi International increases the capacity and effectiveness of the Pax Christi movement and global network. Frequent continental and regional gatherings play a key role in facilitating consultation and exchanges among Pax Christi Member Organisations around the world;

history: 13 Mar 1945. Reorganized Dec 1950. Officially consecrated as Movement of the Church, 1952. Also referred to as Pax Christi International. Laureate of the UNESCO Peace Prize 1983. Statutes revised Apr 2006. Registered in accordance with Belgian law.

general_activities.activity_description: The Commission on the Status of Women and UN Women; 4. Offer recommendations to US government agencies on key policies affecting women; 5. Support initiatives to reduce discriminatory practices and policies, including Islamophobia and anti-Semitism, and facilitate cross cultural dialogue for deepened understanding; 6. Provide transformational leadership training to equip women leaders with a range of critical resources and skills to facilitate change, specifically in support of the US National Action Plan for Women, Peace and Security called for under UN SCR 1325;

International Work and Study Camp(Yearly Event): The objective of the camp is to work with youth on the process of Dialogue, mutual understanding and transformation through democracy through workshops, lectures, exercises and field visits. structure: 7 members of the Board and 7 Staff

IRD_def: The Forum for Development, Culture and Dialogue respects the dignity of every human being, values the diversity of cultures in the Middle East, encourages dialogue and understanding as a means of resolving conflict, and perceives justice as the lasting basis of peace.

aim: Promote peacebuilding, equal citizenship, and human rights in the Middle East by creating common spaces for dialogue and building the capacity of community and civil society groups to be catalysts for peace, with a focus on women and youth.

general_activities.activity_name: Construction of Citizenship in the Arab World
general_activities.activity_description: The training aims to explore the compatibility between Arab culture and religions and Human Rights, and to construct an alternative Arab based understanding of citizenship and Human Rights;

The project proposal is aiming for a more just and equitable society through legal reform and the amendment of the sectarian personal status codes through working with religious leaders and building their capacities in their service provision and enhancing their legal literacy on matters that are affected by personal status laws;

The objective is to provide a new perspective of peacebuilding and conflict resolution skills and techniques to civil society leaders, in order to widen their horizons and their capabilities on how they can act for peace in their communities. This project aims to gather young civil society leaders coming from different institutions in Lebanon, such as scouts, religious based institutions for youth, youth committees and clubs;

general_activities.activity_name: Peacebuilding by Active Citizenship in Iraq

general_activities.activity_name: Towards Peacebuilding in a Lebanese Context
general_activities.activity_description: A 3-year project, gathering students of theological and religious institutions in their final two years of study (new group of participants each year) to enhance bridges between future leaders of different confessional backgrounds and to increase linkages and communication among them as well as to deepen the understanding of students of various confessions in Lebanon for peacebuilding and to exchange their points of view on peacebuildling issues.

finances: Member churches' dues. Appropriations from National Committees. Total budget (annual): about US$ 90 million, of which US$ 80 million allotted to projects, programmes and emergencies. LWF Foundation - Endowment Fund: for long-term financial support.

IRD_activities.activity: Lutheran Interreligious Network: Developing a network of churches, agencies and projects involved in interfaith work to share about successes and challenges;
Religions and Renewal/Interfaith Visions for Change: Inviting people from different faith communities to share their visions for renewal and to develop joint theological understanding;

other_relations: Czech Diakonia, Prague, Czech Republic
IRD_def: The LWF strives to put our faith into action within and beyond the communion. This action takes a variety of forms from theological reflection and dialogue with other churches and faiths, to deepening relationships, sharing about our faith, serving those in need and advocating for a more just, peaceful and reconciled world.
events: 2003: The Tenth Assembly, Winnipeg, Canada
2010: The Eleventh Assembly, Stuttgart, Germany
2014: Speaking during two panel discussions at the 28th edition of the international meeting “People and Religions” hosted by the Community of Sant' Egidio, Antwerp, Belgium

2014: Interreligious Symposium Affirms the Values of Dignity, Compassion and Solidarity: 2014: The conference, sponsored by the Lutheran World Federation and the School of Theology and Ministry at Seattle University, engaged thirty Jewish, Christian and Muslim scholars from various traditions in lively and thought-provoking discussions, Seattle, WA, USA
aim: Build up a communion in Christ living and working together for a just, peaceful, and reconciled world.

general_activities.activity_name: Sustainable Livelihoods in a Changing Climate
general_activities.activity_description: With our long track record of community-based development, working to help communities lift themselves out of poverty in harmony with creation;
Working to empower community-led action for human rights, justice, and peace and developing local capacities for leadership and governance and promote access to essential services;

general_activities.activity_name: Disaster Risk Reduction & Emergency Preparedness and Response
general_activities.activity_description: Responding to save lives as disasters unfold and continue to assist vulnerable communities through recovery and rehabilitation and helping communities to pro-actively reduce risks and prepare before disasters strike;
This annual symposium seeks to provide a platform for theological and inter-disciplinary reflection on the topic of work;

Three workshops on rights-based approach principles for church leaders, development workers and theology faculty. Focus is on broad participation of youth, women and persons with diverse skills to strengthen the effectiveness of local churches. Workshops aim to foster a link between church life and the human rights principles for development;

Workshops with seminaries to establish curriculum that ensures the inclusion of human rights dimensions in pastoral formation; 9. Lutheran-Anglican Dialogue; 10. Lutheran-Mennonite Dialogue; 11. Lutheran-Orthodox Dialogue; 12. Lutheran-Reformed Dialogue; 13. Lutheran-Roman Catholic Dialogue;

history: The LWF was established in 1947 as a Federation of Lutheran churches. Lutherans worldwide wanted to confess, reflect, reconcile, and to respond together to human suffering in the aftermath of the Second World War.
